title: Acts Chapter 21 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Acts chapter 21 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Acts Chapter 21 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Acts Chapter 21.

questions.question: After leaving Cyprus, where did Paul and his company land?
options: Tyre
Rhodes
Caesarea
Ptolemais
questions.correctAnswer: Tyre
questions.explanation: Acts 21:3 states that after leaving Cyprus, they sailed into Syria and landed at Tyre.

questions.question: How many days did Paul stay in Tyre with the disciples?
options: Five days
Seven days
Three days
Ten days
questions.correctAnswer: Seven days
questions.explanation: Acts 21:4 mentions that Paul and his company tarried there seven days with the disciples.

questions.question: Who was the prophet that came down from Judea and warned Paul about being bound?
options: Philip
Agabus
Mnason
James
questions.correctAnswer: Agabus
questions.explanation: Acts 21:10-11 describes the prophet Agabus coming down from Judea and binding his own hands and feet with Paul's girdle as a sign.

questions.question: What did Paul say he was ready to do at Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus?
options: To preach only
To be bound and die
To build a church
To travel again
questions.correctAnswer: To be bound and die
questions.explanation: Acts 21:13 records Paul saying he is ready not only to be bound but also to die at Jerusalem for Jesus' name.

questions.question: Who hosted Paul in Caesarea?
options: Philip the evangelist
Agabus
Mnason
James
questions.correctAnswer: Philip the evangelist
questions.explanation: Acts 21:8 states that Paul stayed at the house of Philip the evangelist in Caesarea.

questions.question: How many daughters did Philip have that prophesied?
options: Two
Three
Four
Five
questions.correctAnswer: Four
questions.explanation: Acts 21:9 mentions that Philip had four daughters who prophesied.

questions.question: What was the name of the old disciple from Cyprus with whom Paul lodged in Jerusalem?
options: Mnason
Agabus
Trophimus
Philip
questions.correctAnswer: Mnason
questions.explanation: Acts 21:16 identifies Mnason of Cyprus as the old disciple with whom Paul lodged.

questions.question: Who did Paul meet with the day after arriving in Jerusalem?
options: James and all the elders
Philip and his daughters
Agabus and the disciples
Mnason and brethren
questions.correctAnswer: James and all the elders
questions.explanation: Acts 21:18 states that Paul went in with them unto James and all the elders the next day.

questions.question: What accusation was made against Paul by the Jews from Asia in the temple?
options: Teaching against the people and law
Stealing from the temple
Spreading false prophecy
Ignoring the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: Teaching against the people and law
questions.explanation: Acts 21:28 records that Jews accused Paul of teaching against the people, the law, and the temple.

questions.question: What did the people do to Paul after they laid hands on him in the temple?
options: Took him outside and tried to kill him
Prayed for him
Released him immediately
Sent him to Philip
questions.correctAnswer: Took him outside and tried to kill him
questions.explanation: Acts 21:30-31 describes the crowd taking Paul out of the temple and attempting to kill him.

questions.question: True or False: The chief captain immediately released Paul when the uproar started.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 21:32-33 shows the chief captain took Paul into custody and bound him with two chains.

questions.question: True or False: The crowd called Paul 'the Egyptian' during the uproar in Jerusalem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 21:38 records the chief captain asking Paul if he was the Egyptian who led an uproar previously.

questions.question: True or False: Paul spoke to the people in the Greek language when given permission by the chief captain.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 21:40 states that Paul spoke to the people in the Hebrew tongue, not Greek.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Acts 21:25: 'As touching the Gentiles which believe, we have written and concluded that they observe no such thing, save only that they keep themselves from things offered to _______, and from blood, and from strangled, and from fornication.'
options: idols
meats
animals
unclean foods
questions.correctAnswer: idols
questions.explanation: Acts 21:25 states Gentile believers should keep themselves from things offered to idols, among other things.

questions.question: What did Paul do to show that he was keeping the law before the people in Jerusalem?
options: Purified himself with men who had a vow
Preached in the temple
Fasted for seven days
Broke bread with the elders
questions.correctAnswer: Purified himself with men who had a vow
questions.explanation: Acts 21:26 describes Paul taking men with vows and purifying himself with them to demonstrate his obedience.

medium.title: Acts Chapter 21 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Acts Chapter 21 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is facing a difficult journey and fears what lies ahead. Based on Acts 21, what biblical truth about trust and obedience would you share?
options: Trust in the Lord's will even when warned of danger
Avoid any path that seems risky or uncertain
Only proceed if all circumstances are favorable
Delay action until everyone agrees
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in the Lord's will even when warned of danger
questions.explanation: In Acts 21:4, disciples warned Paul through the Spirit not to go to Jerusalem, yet Paul was ready to obey God's will despite the warning (Acts 21:13-14). This shows faithful trust and obedience to God's plan even in difficulty.

questions.question: How does Acts 21 teach about the importance of prayer and seeking God's guidance in difficult decisions?
options: Paul and the disciples prayed together before departing
Prayer is only necessary after problems arise
Human wisdom alone should guide decisions
Ignore spiritual warnings and proceed quickly
questions.correctAnswer: Paul and the disciples prayed together before departing
questions.explanation: Acts 21:5 describes how Paul and the disciples kneeled and prayed on the shore before parting ways, demonstrating the vital role of prayer and seeking God's guidance in challenging moments.

questions.question: A Christian family is seeking wisdom on raising children in faith. What example from Acts 21 can encourage them?
options: Philip had four daughters who prophesied, showing nurturing of spiritual gifts
Children should not be involved in church activities
Faith is only for adults, children will find their own way
Children’s opinions are not important in spiritual matters
questions.correctAnswer: Philip had four daughters who prophesied, showing nurturing of spiritual gifts
questions.explanation: Acts 21:8-9 mentions Philip the evangelist’s four daughters who prophesied, illustrating the importance of nurturing spiritual growth and gifts in the family setting.

questions.question: According to Acts 21, how should Christians respond to warnings about potential suffering for their faith?
options: Accept trials as part of obedience to Christ
Avoid suffering by compromising beliefs
Ignore all warnings and act recklessly
Only serve God when life is easy
questions.correctAnswer: Accept trials as part of obedience to Christ
questions.explanation: Paul expressed willingness not only to be bound but also to die for Jesus (Acts 21:13), demonstrating a biblical attitude of faithful perseverance through trials as part of Christian obedience.

questions.question: What does Acts 21 teach about humility and submitting to church leadership?
options: Paul reported to James and the elders to share his ministry and receive counsel
Leaders should always follow their own plans without consultation
Submission to leaders is optional for mature believers
Only new believers should listen to church elders
questions.correctAnswer: Paul reported to James and the elders to share his ministry and receive counsel
questions.explanation: Acts 21:18-19 shows Paul meeting with James and the elders, demonstrating humility and respect for church leadership through open communication and accountability.

questions.question: In Acts 21, how is the Christian principle of integrity in daily life demonstrated?
options: Paul purified himself publicly to show he kept the law
Paul ignored accusations and did not clarify his behavior
Secret sin is acceptable if no one knows
Avoid public accountability to maintain reputation
questions.correctAnswer: Paul purified himself publicly to show he kept the law
questions.explanation: Acts 21:24-26 describes Paul taking part in purification rites with four men to demonstrate that he observed the law, showing integrity and transparency in his conduct.

questions.question: How does Acts 21 illustrate the value of fellowship and support among believers during trials?
options: Believers in Tyre and Caesarea accompanied and hosted Paul with care
Paul traveled alone without any companions
Fellowship is only for joyful occasions
Believers should avoid difficult situations together
questions.correctAnswer: Believers in Tyre and Caesarea accompanied and hosted Paul with care
questions.explanation: Verses Acts 21:4-7 and Acts 21:8 show disciples supporting Paul by hosting him and accompanying him part of the way during his journey, highlighting the importance of mutual care and fellowship.

questions.question: What does the response of the believers in Jerusalem to Paul's report teach about gratitude and encouragement in church life?
options: They glorified God and encouraged Paul upon hearing his ministry among Gentiles
They criticized Paul without listening
They ignored his report and did not respond
They were jealous and divided the church
questions.correctAnswer: They glorified God and encouraged Paul upon hearing his ministry among Gentiles
questions.explanation: Acts 21:20 records the brethren glorifying God and encouraging Paul after hearing his report, teaching the value of gratitude and support within church fellowship.

questions.question: When false accusations arise against a believer, how does Acts 21 show one should respond?
options: Paul allowed the authorities to hear his defense calmly
Paul fled to avoid confrontation
Paul responded with anger and violence
Paul ignored all accusations
questions.correctAnswer: Paul allowed the authorities to hear his defense calmly
questions.explanation: In Acts 21:33-40, Paul was arrested but requested to speak to the crowd and gave his defense clearly and calmly, showing wisdom and respect for authority despite false charges.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with fear of persecution. Based on Acts 21, what biblical truth can you share about courage and faith?
options: Paul was ready to face imprisonment and death for Jesus’ name
Believers should avoid any risk of suffering
Faith requires hiding from danger at all costs
Only certain believers are called to suffer
questions.correctAnswer: Paul was ready to face imprisonment and death for Jesus’ name
questions.explanation: Acts 21:13 shows Paul’s readiness to suffer and even die for Christ, teaching that courage rooted in faith enables believers to face persecution boldly.

questions.question: True or False: According to Acts 21, the believers discouraged Paul from going to Jerusalem because they did not want him to face any hardship.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 21:4 and 21:12 show the disciples and others urged Paul not to go to Jerusalem because of the dangers awaiting him, reflecting their concern for his safety.

questions.question: True or False: Acts 21 shows that Paul disregarded church customs and laws in his ministry among the Gentiles.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 21:24-25 explains that Paul followed Jewish laws and customs to avoid misunderstandings, showing respect for the law even while ministering to Gentiles.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: When Paul was arrested, he identified himself as a _____ from Tarsus, a city in Cilicia.
options: Jew
Roman soldier
Greek philosopher
Gentile
questions.correctAnswer: Jew
questions.explanation: Acts 21:39 records Paul stating, 'I am a man which am a Jew of Tarsus, a city in Cilicia,' emphasizing his Jewish heritage and citizenship as part of his defense.

questions.question: How does Acts 21 illustrate the biblical principle of generosity and hospitality among believers?
options: Believers hosted Paul in their homes and accompanied him on his journey
Paul traveled only with paid servants
Hospitality is optional and rarely practiced
Believers avoided welcoming strangers
questions.correctAnswer: Believers hosted Paul in their homes and accompanied him on his journey
questions.explanation: Acts 21:5-8 shows believers welcoming Paul, hosting him in Philip’s house, and accompanying him on part of his journey, demonstrating generosity and hospitality.

questions.question: What lesson about perseverance through trials can we learn from Paul’s experience in Acts 21?
options: Remain faithful and courageous despite opposition and suffering
Give up when facing persecution
Avoid difficult situations to preserve comfort
Only serve God in easy times
questions.correctAnswer: Remain faithful and courageous despite opposition and suffering
questions.explanation: Paul’s journey to Jerusalem despite warnings and his subsequent arrest (Acts 21:4, 21:27-33) teaches believers to persevere faithfully through trials for the sake of the Gospel.

hard.title: Acts Chapter 21 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Acts Chapter 21.

questions.question: In Acts 21, what is the significance of Paul taking part in purification rites with four men who had a vow on them?
options: To demonstrate his observance of the Mosaic Law and dispel rumors about his teachings
To initiate the men into the Christian faith
To perform a Greek ritual of cleansing
To symbolize his separation from Gentile believers
questions.correctAnswer: To demonstrate his observance of the Mosaic Law and dispel rumors about his teachings
questions.explanation: Acts 21:23-26 shows that Paul was advised to purify himself with four men to show the Jews that he still kept the Law, countering accusations that he taught Jews to forsake Moses.

questions.question: Which prophet came down from Judea to Caesarea and gave a symbolic warning to Paul about his future imprisonment?
options: Agabus
Jeremiah
Elijah
Nathan
questions.correctAnswer: Agabus
questions.explanation: Acts 21:10-11 describes Agabus as the prophet who took Paul's girdle and bound his own hands and feet, prophesying Paul's impending capture.

questions.question: True or False: The disciples in Tyre, through the Spirit, encouraged Paul not to go up to Jerusalem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 21:4 clearly states that the disciples in Tyre said to Paul through the Spirit not to go to Jerusalem.

questions.question: What is the literary significance of Paul's girdle being used by Agabus to symbolize Paul's future binding?
options: It is a prophetic typology showing Paul's personal involvement in his foretold suffering
It is a ritual purification act
It represents the breaking of the Law
It was a common Greek symbol of authority
questions.correctAnswer: It is a prophetic typology showing Paul's personal involvement in his foretold suffering
questions.explanation: By using Paul's own girdle, Agabus personalized the prophecy, a literary device emphasizing Paul's direct participation in the predicted events (Acts 21:11).

questions.question: How does Paul's willingness to be bound or even die at Jerusalem relate to Old Testament themes of prophetic suffering?
options: It parallels the suffering servant motif seen in Isaiah
It echoes the conquest narratives of Joshua
It imitates King David's reign
It reflects the wisdom literature's emphasis on prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: It parallels the suffering servant motif seen in Isaiah
questions.explanation: Paul's acceptance of suffering aligns with Isaiah's suffering servant theme, where the servant accepts hardship for God's purposes (Acts 21:13).

questions.question: Which cultural practice is reflected by the Jews shaving their heads after completing a vow, as mentioned in Acts 21?
options: Nazirite vow
Roman citizenship ritual
Greek athletic dedication
Pharisaic purification rite
questions.correctAnswer: Nazirite vow
questions.explanation: Acts 21:23-24 indicates the shaving of heads relates to the Nazirite vow, a Jewish practice described in Numbers 6, showing adherence to the Law.

questions.question: Who was Mnason, and what role did he play in Paul's journey to Jerusalem?
options: An old disciple from Cyprus who hosted Paul in Jerusalem
A Roman centurion who arrested Paul
A prophet who warned Paul
A Greek philosopher who debated Paul
questions.correctAnswer: An old disciple from Cyprus who hosted Paul in Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Acts 21:16 states that Mnason of Cyprus was an old disciple who provided lodging for Paul in Jerusalem.

questions.question: What was the accusation made against Paul by the Jews of Asia in the temple at Jerusalem?
options: That he taught against the people, the law, and the temple, and brought Greeks into the temple
That he was a Roman spy
That he violated the Sabbath by working
That he stole temple treasures
questions.correctAnswer: That he taught against the people, the law, and the temple, and brought Greeks into the temple
questions.explanation: Acts 21:28 accuses Paul of teaching against Jewish people, their law, and temple, and of defiling the temple by bringing Greeks inside.

questions.question: What is the significance of Paul speaking to the crowd in the Hebrew tongue at the end of the chapter?
options: It shows his connection to his Jewish roots and appeals directly to the Jewish audience
It was a secret code to his followers
It was to confuse the Roman soldiers
It was a Greek translation
questions.correctAnswer: It shows his connection to his Jewish roots and appeals directly to the Jewish audience
questions.explanation: Acts 21:40 shows Paul speaking Hebrew to connect with his Jewish audience, emphasizing his identity and authority.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The four daughters of Philip mentioned in Acts 21 were known for their ability to __________.
options: prophesy
heal
sing
teach
questions.correctAnswer: prophesy
questions.explanation: Acts 21:9 states that Philip's four virgin daughters prophesied.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the believers in Jerusalem being 'zealous of the law' while also glorifying God for the work among Gentiles?
options: It shows the tension between adherence to Mosaic Law and acceptance of Gentile believers
It indicates complete rejection of Gentile converts
It reflects a fully Gentile church
It implies that Jewish believers ceased to follow the Law
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the tension between adherence to Mosaic Law and acceptance of Gentile believers
questions.explanation: Acts 21:20 presents the Jewish believers as law-abiding yet rejoicing in Gentile conversions, highlighting early church tensions on Law and grace.

questions.question: What cultural and historical context helps explain the uproar in Jerusalem when Paul was accused of bringing Greeks into the temple?
options: Gentiles were strictly forbidden from entering the inner courts of the temple, provoking outrage
Greeks were highly respected in the temple
The temple was used primarily for Roman worship
There were no restrictions on foreigners in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Gentiles were strictly forbidden from entering the inner courts of the temple, provoking outrage
questions.explanation: Jewish law forbade Gentiles from entering certain temple areas, so Paul's alleged action (Acts 21:28-29) triggered the violent reaction.

questions.question: How does the narrative structure of Acts 21 foreshadow Paul's eventual arrest and trial in later chapters?
options: The prophetic warning and symbolic binding foreshadow his imprisonment and suffering
The peaceful welcome in Jerusalem ends the story
The voyage to Tyre is the climax
The mention of Philip's daughters signals the conclusion
questions.correctAnswer: The prophetic warning and symbolic binding foreshadow his imprisonment and suffering
questions.explanation: Agabus's prophecy binding Paul (Acts 21:11) and subsequent events foreshadow his arrest and trials later in Acts.

questions.question: Which theme in Acts 21 reflects a broader New Testament emphasis on the relationship between Jewish Law and Gentile inclusion?
options: The tension between maintaining the Law and welcoming Gentiles
The rejection of all Jewish customs
The establishment of a new temple in Rome
The abolition of all vows
questions.correctAnswer: The tension between maintaining the Law and welcoming Gentiles
questions.explanation: Acts 21:20-25 discusses the balance between Jewish law observance and Gentile believers' practices, echoing Acts 15 and Pauline epistles.

questions.question: What does Paul's identification as a 'citizen of no mean city' in Acts 21:39 reveal about his social status and its importance in the narrative?
options: It establishes his Roman citizenship and social standing, which later affects his legal treatment
It indicates he was a poor outsider
It means he was a slave
It suggests he was a Greek philosopher
questions.correctAnswer: It establishes his Roman citizenship and social standing, which later affects his legal treatment
questions.explanation: Acts 21:39 highlights Paul's Tarsus citizenship, important for his rights and protection under Roman law.

theological.title: Acts Chapter 21 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Acts Chapter 21 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Acts 21, what warning did the disciples in Tyre give Paul regarding his journey?
options: They said through the Spirit that Paul should not go up to Jerusalem
They warned him of shipwreck on the journey
They told Paul to avoid the Gentiles
They advised Paul to take a different route
questions.correctAnswer: They said through the Spirit that Paul should not go up to Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Acts 21:4 states that the disciples in Tyre, through the Spirit, told Paul not to go up to Jerusalem, indicating a prophetic warning. This reflects God’s sovereign control and foreknowledge (Isaiah 46:10, Acts 20:22-23).

questions.question: What symbolic act did the prophet Agabus perform to prophesy about Paul's future?
options: He bound his own hands and feet with Paul's girdle
He laid hands on Paul to heal him
He poured oil on Paul’s head
He gave Paul a scroll to read
questions.correctAnswer: He bound his own hands and feet with Paul's girdle
questions.explanation: Acts 21:11 describes how Agabus took Paul's girdle and bound his own hands and feet, symbolizing Paul's coming bondage in Jerusalem. This prophetic action illustrates the Holy Spirit’s role in revealing future events (2 Kings 4:29, Ezekiel 37:7).

questions.question: How did Paul respond to the warnings about going to Jerusalem?
options: He was ready not only to be bound but also to die for Jesus
He decided to delay his journey
He ignored the warnings and sailed immediately
He asked the disciples to pray for his safety
questions.correctAnswer: He was ready not only to be bound but also to die for Jesus
questions.explanation: In Acts 21:13, Paul expresses willingness to suffer and die for the name of the Lord Jesus, signifying his total commitment and submission to God's will, reflecting Christ's own example (Philippians 1:20-21, 2 Timothy 4:6-8).

questions.question: What was the purpose of Paul purifying himself with the four men who had a vow?
options: To show that he kept the law and refute accusations
To join a new Jewish sect
To prepare for a Gentile feast
To be baptized again
questions.correctAnswer: To show that he kept the law and refute accusations
questions.explanation: Acts 21:24 explains that Paul took part in purification rites with men who had vows to demonstrate that he lived orderly and kept the law, countering false accusations about forsaking the law (Acts 21:21, Romans 3:31).

questions.question: What instruction was given regarding Gentile believers in Acts 21?
options: They were not required to follow Jewish customs except to avoid idolatry, blood, strangled animals, and fornication
They must be circumcised and follow all Jewish laws
They should not eat with Jewish believers
They were to build separate churches
questions.correctAnswer: They were not required to follow Jewish customs except to avoid idolatry, blood, strangled animals, and fornication
questions.explanation: Acts 21:25 clarifies that Gentiles who believe are not bound by Jewish ceremonial laws except to avoid certain practices, affirming salvation by grace and the unity of the church (Acts 15:20, Romans 14:14-17, 1 Corinthians 8:4-13).

questions.question: Who was Mnason, mentioned in Acts 21, and what role did he play?
options: An old disciple from Cyprus who provided lodging for Paul and companions
A Roman centurion who arrested Paul
A Jewish elder who opposed Paul
A prophet who warned Paul not to go to Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: An old disciple from Cyprus who provided lodging for Paul and companions
questions.explanation: Acts 21:16 identifies Mnason as an old disciple from Cyprus who hosted Paul and the others, demonstrating early Christian fellowship and hospitality (Romans 16:23, Hebrews 13:2).

questions.question: What was the reaction of the Jewish crowd in Jerusalem when they saw Paul in the temple?
options: They stirred up the crowd, seized Paul, and accused him of defiling the temple
They welcomed Paul with open arms
They ignored him and went about their business
They asked Paul to teach in the synagogue
questions.correctAnswer: They stirred up the crowd, seized Paul, and accused him of defiling the temple
questions.explanation: Acts 21:27-28 describes the Jews from Asia accusing Paul of teaching against the law and bringing Gentiles into the temple, inciting the people to violence, revealing religious zealotry and resistance to the gospel (John 2:13-17, Acts 22:21-22).

questions.question: Why did the chief captain order Paul to be bound with two chains?
options: Because of the violent crowd and to keep him secure
Because Paul was a Roman citizen
To take him immediately to trial
To punish him for blasphemy
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the violent crowd and to keep him secure
questions.explanation: Acts 21:33 states that the chief captain bound Paul with two chains due to the crowd’s violence, showing Roman authority’s attempt to maintain order and protect Paul (Acts 16:37, 1 Timothy 1:16).

questions.question: How did Paul identify himself to the chief captain when asked about his identity?
options: As a Jew from Tarsus, a city in Cilicia
As an Egyptian revolutionary
As a Roman citizen from Rome
As a Gentile believer
questions.correctAnswer: As a Jew from Tarsus, a city in Cilicia
questions.explanation: Acts 21:39 records Paul saying he was a Jew from Tarsus, emphasizing his legal citizenship and heritage, which afforded him certain protections, illustrating the intersection of divine providence and human authority (Acts 22:3, Philippians 3:5).

questions.question: What was the significance of Paul speaking to the crowd in Hebrew at the end of the chapter?
options: To address his people in their own language and appeal to their heritage
To confuse the Roman soldiers
To deliver a secret message to the disciples
To recite Old Testament laws
questions.correctAnswer: To address his people in their own language and appeal to their heritage
questions.explanation: Acts 21:40 shows Paul speaking in Hebrew to engage the Jewish crowd directly, using cultural and linguistic context to defend his ministry, reflecting Christ's use of Scripture and language to reach His people (John 5:39, Romans 11:1).

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the theological implication of Paul's willingness to suffer and die in Jerusalem?
options: It exemplifies Christian discipleship and faithfulness unto death
It shows a disregard for personal safety
It indicates a lack of trust in God's protection
It was a political strategy
questions.correctAnswer: It exemplifies Christian discipleship and faithfulness unto death
questions.explanation: Paul’s readiness to suffer and die (Acts 21:13) demonstrates the call to bear one's cross and imitate Christ’s sacrificial love, central to Christian theology (Matthew 16:24, Philippians 3:10, 2 Timothy 2:12).

questions.question: What role does the Holy Spirit play in the events of Acts 21, particularly concerning the warnings given to Paul?
options: The Holy Spirit communicates prophetic warnings and guides believers
The Holy Spirit prevents all suffering for believers
The Holy Spirit directs Paul to avoid Jerusalem
The Holy Spirit causes confusion among the disciples
questions.correctAnswer: The Holy Spirit communicates prophetic warnings and guides believers
questions.explanation: In Acts 21:4 and 21:11, the Spirit reveals future events and warns Paul, showing the Spirit’s role in prophecy and guidance within the church (John 16:13, 1 Corinthians 12:4-11, Romans 8:14).

questions.question: What does Acts 21 reveal about the relationship between Jewish law observance and Gentile believers in the early church?
options: Gentile believers were not required to observe Jewish laws except certain moral and ceremonial restrictions
Gentile believers had to fully adopt Jewish law to be saved
Jewish law was abolished entirely for all believers
Jewish law was only symbolic and not practiced
questions.correctAnswer: Gentile believers were not required to observe Jewish laws except certain moral and ceremonial restrictions
questions.explanation: Acts 21:25 confirms the early church’s decision that Gentiles are not bound by the full law, only certain prohibitions, affirming salvation by grace apart from the works of the law (Galatians 2:16, Ephesians 2:8-9, Acts 15:19-21).

questions.question: How does the public reaction to Paul in Jerusalem illustrate the tension between the gospel and Jewish tradition?
options: The crowd accused Paul of defiling the temple and teaching against the law
The crowd welcomed Paul as a prophet
The crowd ignored Paul's message entirely
The crowd asked Paul to lead a rebellion
questions.correctAnswer: The crowd accused Paul of defiling the temple and teaching against the law
questions.explanation: Acts 21:28 shows the crowd’s charge that Paul taught against the law and brought Gentiles into the temple, illustrating conflict between the new covenant gospel and traditional Jewish religious expectations (Matthew 21:12-13, John 2:19-22).

questions.question: What is the significance of Paul lodging with Philip the evangelist in Caesarea?
options: It shows the interconnectedness and support within the early church community
It highlights Philip’s role as a political leader
It indicates Paul was seeking conversion
It was a secret meeting to avoid persecution
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the interconnectedness and support within the early church community
questions.explanation: Acts 21:8-9 describes Paul staying with Philip and his prophetic daughters, illustrating the fellowship and mutual support among early believers (Romans 12:10, Hebrews 10:24-25, 1 Corinthians 12:25-27).
